column4: hi all! is there some way to install specific packages from gutsy in feisty without doing a complete dist-upgrade?
i don't want to update to the beta of gutsy, but i need the newer nvidia driver...
There is no beta yet ;)
And using the gutsy nvidia driver most likely won't work.
hehe, k, i don't want to install the alpha either ;)...
You can try envy: http://www.albertomilone.com/nvidia_scripts1.html
hm, isn't there some way to tell aptitude or something to just pull in the one package from gutsy (with its dependencies of course)?
There is, but it would also install the gutsy kernel... and this might break hundreds of other things.
Drivers are not just like applications, they are tied to the kernel.
hm, i don't mind installing the newer kernel, been using gentoo for years.. i just don't want to clutter up my fs with installing the proprietary driver from their script...
envy is most probably the easiest way to get a new nvidia driver. Not that I ever used it. :)
In that case you should find out how to package a self-compiled nvidia driver... still easier than pulling the gutsy kernel imho... but that might be wrong. :)
hehe, the message from ubotu makes me wonder if envy is so good ;)
Seeing that many people want newer nvidia drivers, I'm pretty sure somebody already packaged it anyway... try the forums?
yeah, i've been searching for it, but all i could find was a hotwo which was using the installer's script
how would i tell aptitude to install just that one package + deps of gutsy?
Also, manually installing the driver won't clutter your fs... I'm pretty sure it's only a couple of files in a seperate directory in /lib/modules.
in case something breaks that's not too bad, i'd just install kubuntu again ;)
hm.. i'd still prefer using the one package from gutsy... just can't figure out how to install it in feisty...
No idea about the gutsy kernel thing... there must be some documentation online, because I heard it's necessary for feisty users on MacBook to use a newer kernel (because of wireless)
http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=511974
aah, thanks a lot, that was exactly what i was looking for :)
It even has some suggestions for nvidia ;)
yeah, just saw this too... thanks :-)
